citation.article-title: Rhodococcus phenolicus sp. nov., a novel bioprocessor isolated actinomycete with the ability to degrade chlorobenzene, dichlorobenzene and phenol as sole carbon sources

p.s: Description of Rhodococcus phenolicus sp. nov.
R. phenolicus (phenolicus (phe.nol.i’.cus. N. L. n. phenol common name for industrial solvent hydroxybenzene; N.L. masc. adj. phenolicus pertaining to phenol).
Cells are non-spore forming, non-motile, Gram-positive and pleomorphic.
Extensive substrate mycelia are observed on TSA, BUG and nutrient agar plates during early growth phases.
Mycelia branch into rods and cocci of variable size during later growth phases.
Aerial mycelia are formed when grown using phenol, chlorobenzene, 1,4-dichlorobenzene and chlorobenzoic acid as sole carbon sources.
Colonies on TSA are variable in morphology, being predominantly rugose and radiate in texture, undulate in margin and umbonate in elevation.
Mucoid, smooth and irregular colonies are a minority.
All colonies develop pale pink pigmentation during stationary phase.
A wide pH range is tolerated.
Optimal, lush growth occurs at pH 6–8, and moderate growth occurs at pH 4, 5, 9 and 10 TSB or M9 with 0.1% glucose as a sole carbon source.

Phenol degradation as a sole carbon source also occurred over a pH range of 4–10, and growth at a phenol concentration of 0.75% (w/v) at pH 7 was observed after 8 days of incubation at 30 °C: catalase positive; oxidase and DNAse negative.
Tween-80 is hydrolyzed.
Tyrosine is hydrolyzed slowly, with clearing of tyrosine around colonies occurring after 1 week of incubation at 30 °C.
Xanthine, urea, esculin, arbutin, casein and starch are not hydrolyzed.
Acid was produced from trehalose, but not from d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, d-xylose, d-fructose, d-glucose, maltose, d-cellobiose, inulin, lactose, d-galactose, d-raffinose, L-arabinose or starch.
Acetate, succinate, ethanol, maltose and pyruvate are utilized.
Utilizes the aromatic compounds phenol, chlorobenzene, 1,4-dichlorobenzene and chlorobenzoic acid as sole carbon sources.
Exhibits weak growth using toluene and biphenyl as the sole carbon source.
The major fatty acids are C16:0, C18:1cis9, 10 methyl-C18:0, and a summed feature of C16:1cis7 and/or C15:0 iso 2-OH.
The DNA G+C content is 66.7 mol%.
The type strain, G2PT, has been deposited in the DSMZ as DSMZ 44812 and in the ARS collection (Peoria, Illinois, USA) as B-24343.
